Materials and Solution Structure Research Group, Interdisciplinary Excellence Centre, Institute of Chemistry, University of Szeged Aradi vértanúk tere 1 Szeged H-6720 Hungary Series of CoxM1-xAl4 layered triple hydroxides, LTHs were prepared as catalyst precursors for hydrogenation of biomass compound cinnamaldehyde under flow and batch reaction conditions. To this end, we have successfully extended the eco-friendly family of Al-rich layered double hydroxides (LDHs) by synthesizing MnAl4-LDHs, furthermore Co3Al-, Co2Al-LDHs were also exploited. Both the magnetic Co-rich and Al-rich reduced forms behaved as robust, efficient and reusable catalysts with significantly different selectivities correlated with their acid-base properties. Al-rich solids showed increased acidity and lower basicity resulting in high hydrocinnamaldehyde selectivity (∼75 %), while the Co-rich catalysts attested enhanced hydrocinnamyl alcohol production (∼80 % selectivity) due to their low acidity and high basicity (mapped by NH3/CO2 temperature programmed desorption tests). Incorporation of Mn, Ni, Cu and Zn ions generally decreased the total acidity of Al-rich catalysts, while their Lewis basicity largely increased: the highest was found for Mn, resulting in activity similar to that of Co-rich catalysts. Stoichiometry of most LDHs can be represented generally by the following formula: [M(II)1-xM(III)x(OH)2]x+[Am− x/m⋅yH2O)]x−, where M(II/III) are di- and trivalent metal ions, x = M(III)/[M(II) + M(III)] and Am− are exchangeable interlamellar anions with a charge of m. Positive charge of hydroxide layers stems from the isomorphic substitution of divalent metal ions by trivalent ones. For charge compensation, anions with water molecules are built (intercalated) into the interlayer space [5]. In one of the most frequently researched field, LDHs serve as catalysts, catalyst precursors or supports in pristine, calcined or reduced forms. These systems contain various active sites; metals in elemental form, Lewis acid (cations), base (O2−) centers and Brønsted acid/base (surface hydroxyls) sites. As precursors, they are excellent candidates in generating highly dispersed metallic or oxide nanoparticles [6]. Aluminum hydroxide based variants mean unique and relatively fresh members of the LDH family [7]. In these Al-rich, monovalent or divalent metal-poor compositions, the evolution of LDH-type structure can be described by the filling of octahedral holes with M(I)/(II) metal ions in the layers of Al(OH)3 polymorphs (mainly gibbsite or bayerite). The positive charges thus formed are compensated by interlayer anions and these LDHs can be described by the following formula: [M(I)2/M(II)Al(III)4(OH)12]2+[Am− 2/m⋅yH2O)]2−. So far, the successful incorporation of Li+ and Mg2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+ ions was reported by impregnating the Al(OH)3 particles with an aqueous solution of metal salts, using mainly harsh reaction conditions (concentrated solution, hydrothermal environment). Incorporation of cations is determined by a selectivity series, where Li+ and Ni2+ are found at the front and Mg2+ at the end [7,8]. Mechanism of the Al-rich LDH formation is still not completely understood [9], but several limiting factors for the incorporation of metal ions had been revealed in the last few years. The main ones are the hydration enthalpies and the ionic radii of cations [10]. As a further key factor, we have investigated the rate constants of water-exchange too [8]. These LDHs have excellent and modified ion exchange capabilities (relative to the conventional M(OH)2 based members) [11] and are promising candidates for eco-friendly catalytic applications, due to their low-alkali/transition metal content embedded in the Al-OH framework [12]. Besides being an excellent and popular model reaction for comparing the performance of different heterogeneous hydrogenation catalysts [13–20], the reduction of cinnamaldehyde (CAL) is also of industrial relevance for the production of valuable by-products from various biomass based α,β-unsaturated aldehydes. More specifically, hydrocinnamaldehyde (HCAL, mainly used in pharmaceutical fields) can be obtained via the hydrogenation of CC bond, cinnamyl alcohol (COL, for flavors) via the reduction of CO bond, and hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCOL, for perfumes) via the total hydrogenation [21,22]. Although the hydrogenation of CC bond is kinetically and thermodynamically more favorable than that of CO bond, not only the selective transformation of CAL to COL, but also to HCOL or especially to HCAL has been the target of much research to date [23–25]. The most commonly used strategies to obtain the desired products are usually based on the modification of electrical properties of the catalysts (addition of other metals or promoters) and of the interactions between the catalysts and supports [26]. It has been shown in several works that even under mild reaction conditions high HCAL and COL selectivities (ca. 90 %), can be achieved using noble Pt or Pd based catalysts, especially when dispersed in various high porosity carbon frameworks [27,28]. However, their industrial application is limited by their complexity and high cost of the manufacturing. Development of LDH/LTH based systems is a cheap and easy way to produce intermetallic compound (IMC) or mixed metal oxide (MMO) catalysts, useful in CAL hydrogenations. The ordered MMO matrix possesses a relatively high specific surface area and pore volume, extremely well dispersed surface defect/metallic/acidic/basic sites and stable metal-support connections preventing from metal leaching [29]. The most commonly researched catalyst arrangements contain Pt or Pd (in some rare cases Ru or Ir) nanoparticles deposited on pristine or calcined MgAl- [30–33], Mg/Zn/Ni/CoFe- [34–36] or CoAl-LDHs [37–41]. These MMO systems can help to stabilize noble metal nanoparticles and tune their catalytic performance through strong interactions. The OH moieties and oxygen vacancies can activate and the Lewis acid metal centers can aid the adsorption of CO/CC groups [42,43]. In order to reduce costs, a lot of research has recently been focused on exclusively using more readily accessible transition metals, mainly Co and Ni, but there are also examples of using solids containing other relatively cheap elements such as Mn, Cu and Zn [26, 44–48]. The latter metals has been associated with an increase in conversion and selectivity due to their diverse acid-base and redox properties. Moreover, their presence as promoters was able to aid the growth of metallic crystals, and to modify the formation of spinel-type MMO particles and thus the distribution of active centers. Catalysts fabricated from cobalt-rich LDHs generally show higher chemoselectivity in the reduction of CO bond, which can be improved with additional active sites provided by the more electropositive metals such as Ga or In in the IMCs formed [22,49]. In addition, the alumina content was described to prevent the sintering of cobalt particles even at temperatures as high as 800 ○C. In contrast, catalysts of Ni-LDH origin show a higher conversion and selectivity tendency for hydrogenation of CC groups [22,50]. With the use of Sb or Bi, it has been reported that the activation of CO group on Ni atoms could be facilitated by steric hindering effect [51], while an MgAl oxide carrier with abundant acid-base sites could promote the adsorption of CO bond and thus the formation of COL [52]. Over the past decades, continuous-flow hydrogenation reactor designs have gradually become a financially and environmentally sustainable alternative to conventional batch-type reactors, specifically for industrial uses [53]. Packed-bed systems are very popular not only because of their easy scalability and safe operation, but also because the contact (residence) time between reactants and the active reactor zone can be easily controlled by varying the flow rate. Thus, reactants continuously passing through the charged columns can interact with superstoichiometric amounts of catalysts, resulting in increased reaction rates, opening new pathways and thus unprecedented selectivity values [54]. Despite the many advantages, studies on the hydrogenation of CAL in flow reactors is still scarce and catalysts containing Pt [55–57], Pd [58], Ru [59] or Ni [60] were mainly examined. To the best of our knowledge, there is also only one example of the use of a Co based catalysts in vapor phase flow system [61]. In this work, we aimed to further extend the still narrow family of Al-rich LDHs and LTHs in order to exploit them as eco-friendly catalyst precursors in CAL hydrogenations under continuous-flow condition in liquid phase. Our attention was focused on combining the catalytic effect of high Al(III) and low transition metal content, therefore conventional Co2Al-, Co3Al-LDHs were also synthetized and tested for comparison. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Details are given in the Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI) document. 2.2 Synthesis of the aluminum-rich LDHs Preparations were based on our previous work [12], started by the mechanochemical activation of the gibbsite particles in a mixer mill (Retsch MM400) with the following fixed operation parameters: 12 Hz grinding frequency, 6 h dry-milling, 100 ball/sample weight ratio. Next step was the stirring of milled Al(OH)3 (250 mg) in aqueous solution (5 cm3) of metal chloride salts at room temperature for 6 days under air atmosphere. For the incorporation of cobalt/zinc, nickel and copper ions, the 2:1, 1:2 and 1:3 M(II):Al initial molar ratios were applied, respectively. In the case of work with Mn(II), the initial Mn:Al ratio and the reaction temperatures were varied in wide range and finally, all solids were washed with distilled water, filtered (0.45 μm pore size) and dried at 70 °C overnight. Syntheses under H2 atmosphere (supplied by Messer Ltd., H2 purity 5.0) followed a similar procedure, but required additional special attention; they started by the mixing of milled Al(OH)3 and MnCl2∙4 H2O particles in N2 (purity 4.5) filled glovebox by deoxygenated (N2 purging) distilled water in glass tubes. Under N2, these were placed into vertical autoclaves and the H2 pressure was adjusted to ∼40 bar in their insides. The resulting dispersions were thermostated in oil bath and were mechanically mixed via using an external magnetic stirrer. 2.3 Preparation of the conventional LDHs and aluminum-rich LTHs LDHs with 2:1 and 3:1 Co:Al molar ratios were synthetized by using the relatively straightforward co-precipitation route [3,22]. Aqueous solutions of CoCl2∙6 H2O (0.45 and 0.30 M) and AlCl3∙6 H2O (0.15 M) were blended dropwise with a base solution (3 M NaOH). The obtained dispersions were stirred (500 rpm) for two days at room temperature under N2 at around pH 12. CoxM1-xAl4 layered triple hydroxides were generated by the mechanochemically-assisted way described above, implementing the co-incorporation of M(II) ions by mixing the solutions of the required metal salts with gibbsite. Molar ratios of the incorporated M(II) ions were tuned via changing the initial molar ratio of the starting metal chlorides at fixed 2:1 Co:Al molar ratio. Excess of metals was adjusted on the basis of the different impregnation ability of M(II) ions quantified in our previous study [8]. The washing, filtering and drying of LDHs and LTHs was carried out as described above. 2.4 Reduced catalyst preparation Various LDHs/LTHs derived catalysts were generated by the direct reduction of solids (denoted as R-Co2Al, R-Co3Al, R-CoAl4 or R-CoxM1-xAl4, where M = Mn, Ni, Cu, Zn). Pristine hydroxides were taken into tube furnace and heated by 25 °C/min rate up to 650 °C maintaining this temperature for 1 h. Atmosphere of the furnace was the flow of 150 cm3/min H2 and 50 cm3/min N2 (purchased from Messer Ltd., H2 purity 2.5 and N2 purity 4.5). 2.5 Catalytic procedure of the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde Continuous-flow hydrogenation in liquid phase was carried out in a slightly modified H-Cube® flow reactor system (H2 was produced by electrolysis of water). Hydrogen was fed into a valve that modulated the quantity of hydrogen gas released into the solvent stream. Intense mixing of the two phases was ensured by a porous titanium frit, which allowed the hydrogen bubbles to be reduced in size and thus diffuse efficiently into the liquid phase. All the hydrogen produced in this set-up was applied in situ. Further information on the operation and usability of the H-Cube® reactor can be found in the inventors' publication [62]. The catalysts were loaded into heated stainless steel column (reactor) with internal dimensions of 4.6 × 100 mm, diluted with 1.9 g SiO2 (to reduce the aggregation of particles and the formation of larger flow channels, silica with total volume of 1 cm3 and particle size of 0.1–0.8 mm). CAL was dissolved in 4 cm3 isopropanol (IPA), pumped through the preheated catalyst bed (using a high-precision gas chromatography oven space) and the product solution was sampled using steady-state conditions (Figure S1, "S" is the notation used in ESI). Guided by our past experiences [63], to optimize the flow reaction, the following parameters were systematically varied and their effects investigated: temperature, H2 pressure, flow rate, CAL concentration, composition/quantity of the catalysts. In order to prevent from the undesired deactivation of catalysts leading to incorrect interpretation of the results and to gain a better insight into the changes in catalyst structure/composition during reactions, flow hydrogenation was used instead of continuous-flow hydrogenation (which can also be regarded as interrupted continuous-flow hydrogenation) for the reaction operation and catalyst quality comparison tests. In these cases, IPA solution was flowed (30 min, 0.5 cm3/min) through the system before loading the 4 cm3 reaction volume to get the desired operating parameters and reliable processing. After the reaction, the system was also washed with IPA to remove reaction residues from the catalyst and from the internal surfaces of the reactor. During the long-term stability tests, no washing steps were applied so that the catalysts could be compared in such continuous-flow hydrogenation [64–67]. Product solutions were analyzed via using 1H NMR (proton nuclear magnetic resonance) spectroscopy (Bruker Avance NEO 500 spectrometer operating at 500 MHz) and gas chromatography – mass spectroscopy (GC-MS, Thermo Scientific Trace 1310 and ISQ QD single quadrupole mass spectrometer). For batch hydrogenation, vertical stainless steel autoclaves were used with external magnetic stirrers under reaction conditions comparable to those in the flow system. 4 cm3 of IPA-CAL and SiO2/catalyst mixture (in the mass and composition used for flow tests, thus minimizing particle aggregation and adhesion to the magnetic stirrer bars) was loaded into glass tubes of the same volume, which were placed in the autoclaves under air atmosphere. Autoclaves were flushed several times with hydrogen (H2 purity 5.0) and finally the pressure was set to 50 bar. Reaction started by inserting the autoclaves into the preheated oil baths laid on the magnetic stirrers. Products were monitored by the methods described above. 2.6 Structural characterization by instrumental methods LDHs, LTHs, hydrogen reduced and spent catalysts were investigated by powder X-ray diffractometry (XRD) using International Centre for Diffraction Data (ICDD) files, Raman and Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopies, scanning electron microscope coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDX) and thermogravimetric analysis applying mass spectrometer (TG-MS). Ammonia and carbon dioxide temperature programmed desorption (NH3/CO2-TPD), hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and N2 adsorption-desorption tests were performed by using a BELCAT-A catalyst analyzer. Elemental composition of catalysts and product solutions were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). Exact measurement conditions are described in ESI. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Imbibition of the Mn(II), attempt to prepare gibbsite based MnAl4-LDHs To obtain CoxMn1-xAl4-LTH catalyst precursors, the feasibility of Mn(II) incorporation into the octahedral holes of gibbsite was investigated. To date, one of the main problems was the high reaction temperature (120−150 °C) required for the hydrothermal syntheses leading to the oxidation of Mn(II) species [68,69]. In our former studies, the high-energy milling activation of Al(OH)3 particles proved to be the key step to prepare LDHs even at room temperature [8,12], these observations led us to test the synthesis of MnAl4-LDHs. Initial XRD analyses showed promising results; the most intense reflections of conventional LDH phase could be observed around 11° and 23° 2θ. The effect of four operation parameters were tested in detail; the mechanical activation duration of Al(OH)3 and the impregnation time of Mn(II) solutions proved to be the less decisive, 6 h milling and 6 days impregnation proved to be sufficient. Temperature and initial Mn:Al molar ratio of the as-prepared dispersions showed high influence on the formation of average crystallite sizes of LDHs, or otherwise on the crystal thicknesses from layers built into each other [8] ( Fig. 1A, B). This indicator ranged between 7 and 16 nm during the synthesis optimization and helped us to produce the best crystallized solids, but even so, phase-pure MnAl4-LDHs could not have been achieved. At room temperature or lower, the octahedral holes were not completely filled, thus a part of the starting Al(OH)3 (ICDD#01–070–2038) remained intact, meantime the increase of temperature induced the dehydration of gibbsite into boehmite, AlO(OH) (ICDD#01–073–6509). Cooling of the reaction medium aided the formation of thicker LDH crystals up to a point (Fig. 1A), presumably, at lower temperature the oxidation of Mn(II) ions was less pronounced, but coupled with slower metal imbibition. At higher temperature, the formation of amorphous (invisible for XRD) brown solids indicated the oxidation of Mn(II) into Mn(III/IV) species. To avoid this side reaction, the incorporation was also tested under H2 atmosphere and at elevated temperatures (not shown); although the Mn(II) ions did not undergo oxidation, LDH formation was again not favoured. This indicated that the higher temperatures could have an additional negative effect on the incorporation of Mn(II) ions. One possible explanation is the change in the distribution of various Mn(II) chloride species as a function of temperature [70]: while at room temperature Mn(II) is the dominant ion, at higher points the formation of the larger MnCl+ and MnCl2 0 species increases, making the access of Mn(II) ions in the limited size of octahedral holes more difficult. Although, the preparation of phase-pure product was not successful by solely impregnating the Mn(II) ions, the experiments proved that even this large cation (83 pm Shannon–Prewitt radius) could fit into the octahedral holes. Incorporation may have been facilitated by the lowest hydration enthalpy compared to other M(II) ions (for example, −2105 kj/mol for Ni2+ and −1841 kJ/mol for Mn2+ [71]) and their relatively rapid water-exchange rates (faster than Ni2+, Co2+ and Mg2+, similar to Zn2+ and lower than Cu2+ [72]). For the best-crystallized solids, the reflections of LDH phase could be identified based on the diffraction patterns of the relevant NiAl4−Cl−- and MgAl4−Cl−-LDHs [12,73]. Basal distance (0.76 nm), calculated from the position of the first reflections, is characteristic for the chloride ions predominantly present in the interlayer gallery. SEM-EDX and ICP measurements could serve with further indirect proofs for the successful LDH formation; the spatially-resolved elemental mapping of solids indicated the uniform distribution of Al, Mn and Cl atoms and no segregations were seen (Fig. 1C). ICP-MS analyses attested the absence of Fe (from the abrasion of steel milling bodies) and the molar ratio of Mn:Al:Cl was generally around 1:10:2 in the solids. Other key aspects for the successful formation of MnAl4-LDHs (Fig. S2, S3, S4, S5) and the unique cation-exchange capacity of Al-rich LDHs are described in the ESI paper. Finally, it is worthy to highlight the importance and limitations of mechanical pretreatment of gibbsite. Williams et al. investigated the incorporation of various M(II/III) using wet-grinding by a rolling mill [7]. According to their experiments, there were no evidence for LDH formation, when the imbibition of Mn(II) was attempted. Based on the results from our former studies and the recent work, it can be concluded that the intensity and character of mechanical activation step were key parameters for the successful preparation of NiAl4-LDHs with various interlayer anions [12], CuAl4-LDHs free from copper hydroxide side products [8], and even of incorporation of Mn(II) ions which was previously considered to be impossible. This is confirmed by the work of Alex et al. [74]. They studied the effect of high-energy ball milling on gibbsite, and concluded that it could significantly increase the specific surface area, the number of larger pores, the concentration of crystal defects, and thus the reactivity of particles and the efficiency of mass transfer between liquid and solid phases. It is also worth pointing out that the implementation of high-energy grinding required relatively large ball/sample weight ratios, which was a quantitative limitation for the production of Al-rich LDHs. However, in this and our previous work [12] the second step of the synthesis (mixing activated Al(OH)3 in metal salt solutions) was successfully increased (2.5-, 4-fold) compared to the amounts used in an our early study [8], which is a promising sign for future attempts to scale-up the production of these LDHs. 3.2 Synthesis of the conventional and Al-rich LDHs, LTHs and their H2 reduced forms XRD patterns of Co3Al-, Co2Al- (identification by the help of carbonate [01–076–3252] and sulfate [01–091–0540] interlayer containing CoAl-LDH ICDD files), CoAl4-LDHs and CoxM1-xAl4-LTHs (reflection assignation by the XRD curves of NiAl4−Cl−- and MgAl4−Cl−-LDHs [12,73]) were found to be practically identical, but the average crystallite sizes of conventional LDHs were significantly larger due to the different nature of synthesis ( Fig. 2A). No impurity-related reflection was observed, only Cu2(OH)3Cl particles (ICDD#01–086–1391) were identified when the incorporation of the highest Cu amount was attempted (1.5:1 Co:Cu molar ratio). Preparation of CoxM1-xAl4-LTHs allowed us to further extend the well-known selectivity sequence of the incorporating cations by placement of Mn(II), which proved to be ∼14 times less favored than the insertion of Co(II). Thus, based on Williams et al. [7] and our research [8], the following order can be established: Li(I) >> Ni(II) >> Cu(II) >> Zn(II) > Co(II) >> Mn(II) >> Mg(II) Reduction of LDH/LTHs showed striking differences (Fig. 2B); R-Co3Al and R-Co2Al samples indicated parallel formation of hcp (hexagonal close-packed, ICDD#01–089–4308) and fcc (face-centred cubic structure, ICDD#01–089–4307) Co(0) particles. Al-rich LTHs could be partially transformed into amorphous AlOx, CuAlO2 (ICDD#01–075–1792), stoichiometric (M(II)Al2O4, MnAl2O4 − ICDD#01–084–9313 [75], CoAl2O4 − ICDD#01–075–6033, NiAl2O4 − ICDD#01–087–9915, ZnAl2O4 − ICDD#01–082–1036) and/or the still poorly known substoichiometric spinel-type phases (M(II)Al4O7 [69]) and mainly fcc Co metal with similar crystallite sizes (34−38 nm). For the sample containing copper, fcc Cu (ICDD#01–089–2838) generated next to the Co particles, but no other reflections associated with metal particles were recorded for Ni, Mn and Zn incorporation, meantime reflections characteristic to spinel were pronounced for the latter two metals. The similar XRD patterns suggest that the IMCs may have been formed partly or entirely by dissolution of different metals into Co particles. Reducibilities of CoxAly LDHs were found to highly depend on their composition; as the amount of Al increased, the peaks of maximum H2 consumptions gradually widened and shifted from 365 to 570 °C (data have been normalized for better comparability of H2-TPR curves, Fig. 2C). This clearly indicated that the Al-oxide/hydroxide matrix could inhibit the reduction of Co(II) ions, presumably mainly for kinetic reasons. Thus, only about 60 % of the Co(II) content of CoAl4-LDH was reducible below 800 °C, compared to 85 % and 95 % for Co3Al- and Co2Al-LDHs, respectively. A similar trend was observed for the other Al-rich LDHs (Fig. 2D); M(II) reducibility was around 65 % and 90 % for CuAl4- and NiAl4-LDHs, 80 % for Al(OH)3/MnAl4-LDH system, and only 20 % for ZnAl4-LDH. Most of the samples had overlapping reduction steps, but interestingly, separate processes were recorded for CuAl4-LDH. Very similar observations were made for Cu/zeolite systems [76], where Cu(II) ions were reduced to Cu(I) ions between 200 and 300 °C, and then Cu(I) ions were converted further to Cu(0) around 400 and 600 °C. XRD, TPR results showed that for all solids, a 1-h reduction step at 650 °C was sufficient to generate the elemental form of the different transition metals. 3.3 Comparison of the Co3Al-, Co2Al- and CoAl4-LDHs and their reduced catalyst forms Thermogravimetric curves of LDHs attested relatively similar and expected thermal behaviors ( Fig. 3A). First the physically adsorbed and interlayer H2O evaporated, followed by the departure of structural hydroxyl groups up to ∼400 °C. A large percentage of the total mass change has occurred up to this point, but for CoAl4-LDH a more intense additional loss was observed around 700 °C. Mass spectroscopic analysis showed that, in parallel with the exit of water (m/z = 18), the removal of gas molecules with 36 m/z values were also observed generally from 320 °C (Fig. S6). According to the ICP, SEM-EDX analysis and the literature data [77], this mass change is most likely related to the departure of chloride interlayer anions in the form of HCl, which is further confirmed by the fact that only for CoAl4-LDH, the removal of Cl2 (70 m/z) could be recorded at around 680 and 910 °C. These measurements clearly showed that a significantly higher Cl content can be expected for solids prepared from Al-rich LDH/LTHs by a 650 °C reduction. The acidic centers of catalysts greatly affect the electron density of metal particles and thus the selectivity of the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde [24,43], hence NH3-TPD measurements were performed on the reduced samples, comparing the conventional and the Al-rich LDH precursors (Fig. 3B). Data showed similar strength distributions of the acidic sites; a maximum of weak Brønsted acid sites around 160 °C and a fusion of medium to strong, presumably Lewis acid centers from 230 °C. Brønsted acid sites could be associated with the surface OH groups, while Lewis acid centers could be the Co(II) and the even more electron-deficient Al(III) ions [78,79]. This seems to be supported by the fact that the R-CoAl4 had remarkably higher total acidity than the conventional ones. The same feature was observed for the specific surface area values, where an increase in Al content was accompanied with a gradual rise in surface area (from 42 to 114 m2/g, Table S1). Although a much less researched area, but relationship has been shown between the catalyst basicity and the conversion of CAL hydrogenation [23,42]. On the CO2-TPD curves (Fig. 3C), a sharp peak can be observed around 90 °C for all the three samples, presumably indicating the weak CO2 binding by surface OH groups (Brønsted weak sites), while in the medium/strong basic sites area, CO2 desorption occurred from the Lewis base O2- ions [80]. The latter peak shifts from the maximum of 190 to 320 °C as the Al content is increased, which implies an increase in the strength of basic sites from R-Co3Al to R-CoAl4. An inverse similarity was observed between the results of the CO2- and NH3-TPD analyses, with the R-CoAl4 solid attesting the highest measured acidity and lowest basicity, while the R-Co2Al sample gave the highest basicity and lowest acidity of all the values obtained. Although the differences were shaded by the surface distribution of acidic and basic centers (normalized to the specific surface areas), similar observations could be made considering weak, medium and strong, as well as total acid-base properties (Table S1). The R-CoAl4 sample had the lowest basic site densities, while R-Co2Al had the lowest acid site density. Interestingly, the R-Co3Al catalyst gave intermediate values for the amount of acidity and basicity sites, but due to its smaller specific surface area, it had the highest density of acid-base centers. Finally, the intense peaks (at 200, 482, 523, 691 cm−1, (Fig. 3D) on the Raman spectra of all reduced solids clearly confirmed the formation of normal CoAl2O4 spinel phase [81]. The growing Al content resulted in a gradual increase in the intensity of peaks associated with the Al−O vibrations at 590, 619 and 715 cm−1 [82]. For R-CoAl4 solid, the slight shift of the F 2 g (197 and 520 cm−1) and of the A 1 g (686 cm−1) modes is indicated the distortion of internal vibration of Co(II) [83], which may be related to the formation of some substoichiometric CoAl4O7 spinel-type phase. In agreement with the XRD measurements, it can be stated that the reduced samples contained mainly spinel phases and Al-oxide in addition to elemental metals. 3.4 Cinnamaldehyde reduction under flow conditions: study of the operating parameters 1H NMR and GC-MS analysis confirmed only the formation of the three main product in each case; hydrocinnamaldehyde, cinnamyl alcohol and hydrocinnamyl alcohol (Fig. S1). Reduced form of CoAl4-LDH was used as the starting catalyst and several parameters (cinnamaldehyde/solvent concentration, reaction medium flow rate through the catalyst bed, catalyst space temperature and H2 saturation/pressure, Fig. 4A, B, C, D) determining the flow reactions were systematically varied to map their effect on the reaction. With increasing initial CAL concentration (Fig. 4A) and flow rate (Fig. 4B), a gradual decrease in conversions can be observed. This was clearly due to a reduction in the interactions between the limited active catalytic sites and the aldehyde molecules, which was associated with an increase in the number of CAL molecules with growing concentration, and a decrease in the residence time (from 3.3 to 0.7 min, determined via the flow of a dye solution [84]) of the molecules in catalyst bed with increasing flow rate. COL selectivity values remained relatively unchanged, so that there was a clear relationship between changes in HCAL and HCOL selectivity values, with one value increasing and the other generally decreasing. For both reaction series, a maximum and a minimum in the HCAL and HCOL selectivity values could be reached, respectively, by reducing the conversions to certain levels. As the amount of catalyst elevated, the product distribution curves were similar to those described above. However, here it was coupled with a steadily increasing conversion (Fig. S7). Interestingly, we also observed a change in the selectivity of COL, which moved in parallel with the formation of HCOL and was inversely correlated with the selectivity of HCAL. Durndell et al. reported a similar "volcano dependence" between COL and HCAL formation, and achieved COL selectivities above 60 % by maintaining residence times at an appropriate value using Pt/SiO2 catalyst in a flow reactor system [56]. Elevating the H2 pressure from 10 to 90 bar (Fig. 4D) effectively promoted the transformation of CAL molecules, but above 50 bar a slight slowing down was observed. Similar observations were made by Niesz et al. using a very analogous hydrogenation reactor system between 30 and 90 bar on a Pt/SBA-15 catalyst [55]. Selectivity of HCAL decreased with increasing temperature and H2 concentration, meantime the HCOL production enhanced. Again, HCAL and HCOL selectivity values moved together; towards higher temperatures and H2 concentrations, HCAL selectivity gradually decreased while HCOL production increased. COL selectivity values were also mainly constant although some increases were observed around 30−50 bar. In summary, in our case the HCAL and HCOL selectivity values appeared to correlate in most cases, indicating that the formation of HCOL was generally more favored from HCAL (intermediate) products than from COL. By growing hydrogen saturation, this was presumably due to the prolonged anchoring effect of the strongly adsorbed aldehyde groups on the abundant Lewis acid sites, which might increase the chances of total hydrogenation of the molecules by spending more time near the catalyst surface, whereas this effect was less pronounced when the CO bond was reduced in the first step. Catalyst CAL consumption and product formation rates were also compared for conversion values close to 50 % and 70 % (Table S2). Since it is very difficult to determine the exact number of active sites due to the adsorption of CAL molecules and their partly reduced species on the surface of metallic particles, but also mainly on MMO, we have used the total catalyst surface area for comparison. While CAL transformation and HCAL formation activities were similar in relation to each other around the two conversion points, there was a significant change in COL and HCOL formations. At lower conversions, the generation of COL was more favored, but at higher values, the catalyst became more active in the synthesis of HCOL, and this change was at the expense of HCAL formation to a greater extent. Regarding the effect of the operating parameters, it can be stated that, as expected, increasing the temperature, greatly enhanced the consumption and formation rates, but similar increases were also seen for the reduction of CAL concentrations and flow rates. Both of the latter are likely to be affected by the limited number of catalytically active sites available, as discussed above. By further comparing the activity values at different flow rates (Table S3), it can be clearly seen that the CAL conversion potential of the catalyst increased steadily with the flow rate. This indicates that the process is probably diffusion-controlled, as evidenced by the linear CAL conversion increase with elevating temperature (form 90–210 °C, Fig. 4C) instead of an exponential increase. This may be due to several specific characters of the flow system (limited solute and gas transport between particles, sensitivity to misdistribution of fluids, flow channel formation). This is confirmed by the results showing a linear dependence of conversion values on reaction temperatures, similar dependence was also made by Zhang [58] and Cova et al. [59] using Pd and Ru containing catalysts for continuous-flow CAL reduction. Interestingly, HCAL formation increased gradually between 0.2 and 0.5 cm3/min flow rates, while stagnation was observed for the other products. However, changing the flow rate from 0.5 to 1 cm3/min resulted in a multifold increase in COL and HCOL formation rates (while HCAL value decreased only slightly), which may suggest that at relatively high flow rates the catalyst may become more active towards the reduction of CO bond and the total hydrogenation. 3.5 Effect of chemical composition of the catalyst on CAL hydrogenation First, the catalytic activity of Al-rich LDH precursor was compared with that of conventional Co-rich LDH precursors. The effect of catalyst loading was investigated using identical and variable Co contents with special attention to Co-rich samples ( Fig. 5A, B). To estimate the Co(0) content, the H2-TPR curves were used to calculate the amount of H2 consumed up to 650 °C. Significantly increase in the applied metallic Co amount facilitated the transformation of cinnamaldehyde, but the main product became increasingly HCOL (from 30 to 60 mg for R-Co2Al catalyst loading). This was particularly evident in the case of R-Co3Al, where the selectivities of HCAL and COL products gradually decreased with increasing catalyst mass (from 27 to 81 mg) and thus tripling the metallic Co content, while that of the HCOL product steadily increased, reaching 80 %. It is worth highlighting that at the same amount of reduced Co, (that is 150 mg R-CoAl4 and 27 mg R-Co3Al), the catalysts gave similar conversion values, while the 30 mg R-Co2Al showed a much higher transformation potential of CAL to HCOL. This clearly indicated the priority influence of the surface acidity of catalysts on the selectivity of hydrogenation process, since the total acid sites dispersion obtained for R-CoAl4 and R-Co3Al were significantly higher than that obtained for R-Co2Al solid (Table S1). In the next step, we aimed to further increase the catalytic activity of Al-rich samples by incorporating Ni, Cu, Zn and Mn metals. Increasing Ni content (between 9:1 and 4:6 Co:Ni molar ratio) greatly aided the conversion, but had little effect on selectivity values, the main product remaining HCAL (Fig. 5C, S8). For the incorporation of Ni, Cu and Zn, a 20 mol% substitution of Co was found to be the most efficient, with the highest conversion values measured in all cases at the 4:1 Co:M ratio (R-Co0.8Ni0.2Al4, R-Co0.8Cu0.2Al4, R-Co0.8Zn0.2Al4 catalysts, Fig. 5C, D, E). For the incorporation of Mn, partly different results were obtained (Fig. 5F); the largest increase in conversion was observed with 10 mol% Co substitution (R-Co0.9Mn0.1Al4), while the selectivity values shifted towards COL and even more towards HCOL products. The presence of more electropositive metals in the Co based IMC (i.e., Zn or Mn) would be expected to exert significant changes in the chemoselectivity of the catalysts, but there was no clear trend in the results. It was found that the parameters of acidity and basicity were of key importance at the same reduced Co contents, despite the fact that a number of physico-chemical parameters (such as surface area, porosity, metal dispersity, metal-support interactions, defects) generally interact to affect the activity of catalysts. Increase in the number of basic sites was associated with an enhancement in the rate of hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde, as previously observed on Pd/La2O2CO3 [23] and Pt/MgAl-LDH catalysts [42]. This is supported by the fact that an increase in Lewis basicity was also observed with the incorporation of specific amounts of Ni, Cu, Zn, Mn (Fig. S9). However, an increase in basicity could also reduce the adsorption of the CC bond due to the more electron-rich metal particles and thus increase the selectivity of the COL product [85], which may explain the product distribution observed for the 27 mg R-Co3Al sample. Catalytic results also show that as the total acidity increases, the catalysts become more HCAL selective, confirming that while the overall acidity of the Al-rich samples containing 20 mol% Ni, Cu and Zn was just slightly lower or in some cases significantly higher than that of R-CoAl4 (Fig. S10), the imbibition of Mn (10 mol%) reduced it to a large extent, obtaining a similar value as for R-Co2Al and R-Co3Al. This may be explained by the fact that, although increasing acidity generally promotes activation and adsorption of the CO bond [43], the presence of large amounts of strong acidic sites may also reduce the conversion [86]. However, the less electron-rich metallic sites formed by the electron-withdrawing effect of acidic sites can also help the adsorption of the more electropositive CC moiety (compared to the carbonyl group) due to reduced electron repulsion (which may also indicate some geometric control). In addition, the higher chloride content measured in Al-rich LDH/LTH precursors could also reduce the electron density of the metals [87], and the combination of these may favor the formation of HCAL, this was also observed by Stucchi et al. during the reduction of CAL on a Pt-Mo catalyst [24]. These observations all suggested that the presence of basic or acidic sites alone was not sufficient to achieve high conversion and the desired selectivity in our flow reactions. For this, as described by Zhang et al. on Au based catalysts [80], a balance between acid-base sites was needed, since a synergistic effect could arise between them. This was because increasing acidity could simultaneously help the adsorption of CO and CC bonds, while decreasing basicity could also aid the binding of CC bonds, but at the expense of a decrease in CAL conversion. This was seen in the case of CoAl4-LDH based catalyst (Fig. 5B−F), where the initial high acidity and low basicity parameters could be further tuned by the incorporation of foreign (Ni, Cu and Zn) metals. In these cases, Brønsted base sites remained around 90 °C, while their number decreased only slightly, but a significant increase in the number of Lewis base sites and a shift towards lower temperatures was observed (Fig. S9). Meantime, the Brønsted acidity of samples increased significantly, with a maximum around 160−180 °C, and their Lewis acidity decreased and shifted towards the more intense regions (Fig. S10). Simultaneous variation in the number and strength of Lewis acid-base sites suggests that these centers may have played more dominant role in shaping the activity of Al-rich catalysts than Brønsted sites. Combination of high basicity and low acidity in the R-Co2Al sample resulted in a high conversion towards the fully saturated product due to the largely similar preferential reduction of the CC and CO bonds. Similar considerations applied to the R-Co3Al sample, where only mildly different acid-base properties (slightly higher acidity and lower basicity) compared to the R-Co2Al sample could result in even a COL selectivity above 50 %. In the case of R-Co0.9Mn0.1Al4, maintaining a similar basicity to the other Al-rich samples with a significant decrease in acidity could result in CO and CC saturation activities similar to the Co-rich catalysts. The schematic presentation of these are shown in Fig. 6. Finally, it is also worth mentioning that the different dominance of the reduced forms of Co hcp and fcc in the Co-rich and Al-rich samples, respectively, could certainly have an impact on the CAL hydrogenation (as recently observed between hcp and epsilon Co [88]). In addition, further studies would be needed to separate kinetic and thermodynamic control effects, especially at lower conversions (less than 10 %), but a detailed investigation of these are beyond the scope of our work. 3.6 Scale up – long-term stability tests under flow conditions, hydrogenation in batch reactor In order to test the preparative capabilities and long-term usability of catalysts, scale-up tests of CAL hydrogenation was carried out. In this reaction set-up, the cinnamaldehyde solution (40 cm3) flowed continuously through the catalyst bed without IPA wash interruption steps (meaning absolute continuous-flow hydrogenation process), but the reaction was followed by collecting 4 cm3 of product solutions, with a single portion collection lasting 13.5 min. After more than two hours of continuous application (which means 10 use/portion cycles), none of the catalysts (except for the Mn containing one) showed significant decrease in activity, the packed-bed system and catalysts used were highly stable and robust. R-Co3Al ( Fig. 7A) and R-Co2Al (Fig. 7B) samples retained their high HCOL selectivity performance without significant fluctuations, only the R-Co2Al showed a slight decrease in COL selectivity and an increase in HCOL selectivity over time. Similar observations were made for Al-rich samples; R-Co0.8Ni0.2Al4 showed consistently high HCAL selectivity with minimal conversion loss (Fig. 7C). Only the Mn containing solid attested a rapid decrease in conversion together with a steady increase in HCAL selectivity, while COL formation decreased slightly and HCOL selectivity reduced significantly (Fig. 7D). These changes in activity/selectivity could be partially reversed by an intermediate IPA wash (indicated by the red dashed line in the figure), but further use also resulted in a rapid decrease in conversion. Leached metal was only detected for Co, in a small amounts, typically a few hundred ppb in the reaction products. To better understand/assess the robustness and stability of catalysts, at the end of the long-term stability studies, the spent solids were largely cleaned from SiO2 particles by magnetic separation and analyzed. Except for the silica reflections, XRD analyses gave a pattern consistent with the catalysts before use (Fig. S11). For R-Co2Al and R-Co3Al samples, the most visible sign was that of hcp Co particles, while for the Al-rich samples, reflections of fcc Co were visible and again with the incorporation of Mn, the spinel-type phases signals were still amplified. Infrared spectroscopy confirmed the presence of organic impurities in the catalysts; signs of C−H, CC, C−O and carbonyl groups [89,90] were faintly visible next to the small Si−O vibrations (Fig. S12). Peaks of contaminants were strongest for the R-Co0.9Mn0.1Al4 sample, which is consistent with the possibility of catalyst regeneration observed as a result of IPA washing step (Fig. 7D). Finally, to explore the advantages of flow catalysis in our system, the hydrogenation of CAL was also carried out under batch conditions, by using the reaction conditions identical to those of the flow tests. Up to 180 min reaction time, the conversions for all catalysts showed a steady increase ( Fig. 8A, B, C) approaching values above 90%, interestingly with the incorporation of Mn the highest point around 97% was obtained (Fig. 8D). Selectivity values showed very similar trends to those obtained under flow conditions; for R-Co3Al, R-Co2Al and R-Co0.9Mn0.1Al4 samples, the main product was HCOL, and the R-Co0.8Ni0.2Al4 catalyst also had partly higher chemoselectivity in the reduction of CC bond, especially at shorter reaction times. Overall, however, it can be concluded that under flow conditions the catalysts showed a more selective operation, than in batch reactions, where in many cases a more intense formation of COL (between 20 % and 40 % selectivities) was observed besides the HCOL main product. Furthermore, in all cases (except for the R-Co0.8Ni0.2Al4 solid) formation of β-methylstyrene (generated from COL [91,92]) was observed even with selectivity values up to 10 %. It clearly shows that under batch conditions, in addition to the reduction of CC and CO bonds, the C−OH hydrogenolysis side reaction also took place further reducing the rate of formation of COL and HCOL products. These reactions provide further evidence of the need for better dissemination of the use of flow systems in academia as well as in the industry, as improving the selectivity of processes is almost always the primary goal in research. The most striking difference was, however, observed in the time efficiency of the syntheses under batch and continuous-flow conditions. Working in the same volume, under flow conditions (13.5 min), CAL could be reduced in almost ten times faster than in the batch reaction (about 140 min), with a similar conversion. If the time spent by the starting materials in the pump and intermediate tube sections is not taken into account, only the residence time spent in the active reactor zone (2.2 min), an even faster (more than 60-fold), marked chemical enhancement can be attributed to the flow reaction. In this context, it is worth pointing out that the use of flow systems not only results in shorter operating times, which often directly translates into lower energy and material requirements, but also offers a number of advantages from safety points of view. Just to mention the most important ones, by using continuous-flow hydrogenation systems, the production process can be fully automated and thus remotely monitored/controlled, catalysts can be readily separated (easier maintenance) and the risk of hydrogen explosion can be minimized [53,93]. Using expensive Pt, Pd, or Ru metals, CAL conversions similar to ours could be generally achieved under milder (at 60−90 °C) flow conditions [55–59, 85]. However, our Al-rich catalysts can compete with recently introduced 3D metal printing catalytic flow systems containing even Pt and Ni, Co at similar reaction temperatures and residence times [60]. Extending the comparison to other batch reactor systems (Table S4), it can be seen that the use of conventional LDH catalyst precursors with large transition metal content is associated with similarly high reaction temperatures and often significantly longer reaction times. Therefore, we believe that there is remarkable potential for the future of transition metal-poor, Al-rich LDH/LTH based catalysts due to their ease of preparation and tuning of catalytic performance, as well as favorable environmental and economic sustainability aspects. 4 Conclusions Mn(II) ions have been successfully incorporated into the octahedral holes of gibbsite layers to form unique Al-rich LDHs with chloride, bromide and sulfate interlayer anions. Phase-pure synthesis of MnAl4-LDHs could not be achieved by varying the synthesis parameters. It was, however, possible to find the place of the Mn(II) ions in the incorporation affinity series of a series of metal ions. The current work also highlighted the key importance of mechanochemical pretreatment of gibbsite. Post-filling of the remaining octahedral holes to produce Mn containing LTHs was not possible due to the cation-exchange capacity of these nanostructures, but by using the co-incorporation technique, we were able to create several CoxM1-xAl4-LTHs where M = Mn, Ni, Cu, Zn. Catalytic activity of H2 reduced Al-rich LDH/LTHs was exploited in CAL hydrogenation under flow conditions, comparing the results with the activity of Co-rich samples (obtained via reducing the conventional Co3Al- and Co2Al-LDHs). The Al-rich catalysts competed with the Co-rich samples and showed high HCAL selectivity. Co3Al- and Co2Al-LDHs based solids led to a total reduction, yielding mostly HCOL. Al-rich LTH precursors prepared by incorporating Mn, Ni, Cu and Zn showed enhanced activity compared to the reduced CoAl4-LDH while retaining high HCAL selectivity, except for Mn, where HCOL formation became more favorable at a Co:Mn ratio of 9:1. The altered catalytic performance correlated well with the modification of the overall acid and Lewis base properties, but the applied reduced Co content also strongly influenced the product distribution. In scale-up/long term stability studies under flow conditions, both Co-rich and Al-rich catalysts were found to be robust with stable high HCOL and HCAL forming capacities, respectively. Compared to the batch reaction conditions, working in a flow reactor resulted in significantly faster CAL conversion (2.2 min residence time/13.5 min operating time vs 140 min reaction time) with lower selectivity values of the COL and no formation of β-methylstyrene side product. coredata.dc:description: Series of CoxM1-xAl4 layered triple hydroxides, LTHs were prepared as catalyst precursors for hydrogenation of biomass compound cinnamaldehyde under flow and batch reaction conditions. To this end, we have successfully extended the eco-friendly family of Al-rich layered double hydroxides (LDHs) by synthesizing MnAl4-LDHs, furthermore Co3Al-, Co2Al-LDHs were also exploited. Both the magnetic Co-rich and Al-rich reduced forms behaved as robust, efficient and reusable catalysts with significantly different selectivities correlated with their acid-base properties. Al-rich solids showed increased acidity and lower basicity resulting in high hydrocinnamaldehyde selectivity (∼75 %), while the Co-rich catalysts attested enhanced hydrocinnamyl alcohol production (∼80 % selectivity) due to their low acidity and high basicity (mapped by NH3/CO2 temperature programmed desorption tests). Incorporation of Mn, Ni, Cu and Zn ions generally decreased the total acidity of Al-rich catalysts, while their Lewis basicity largely increased: the highest was found for Mn, resulting in activity similar to that of Co-rich catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Continuous-flow hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde over catalysts derived from modified CoAl4 layered double hydroxides incorporating Mn, Ni, Cu and Zn ions
